Influence of the composition/texture of Mn–Na–W catalysts on the oxidative coupling of methane Thomas Serres Cindy Aquino Claude Mirodatos Yves Schuurman ⁎ IRCELYON, Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse et l’Environnement de Lyon, UMR5256 CNRS-Université de Lyon1, 2 Avenue Albert Einstein, 69626 Villeurbanne, France IRCELYON, Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse et l’Environnement de Lyon UMR5256 CNRS-Université de Lyon1, 2 Avenue Albert Einstein Villeurbanne 69626 France ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +33 472445482; fax: +33 472445399. Graphical abstract Mn–Na–W silica supported catalysts are highly selective toward ethylene and ethane in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) process. However, they present lower activities than La/Sr/CaO catalysts and subsequently a lower ethylene productivity. Optimisation of the Mn–Na–W catalysts has been focused within the range of 2–8wt% of active elements relative to the support, while silica is partially converted into inert cristobalite. This study focused on the increase of the activity of Mn–Na–W catalysts while maintaining their intrinsically high C2 selectivity. The increase in the concentration of the active elements with respect to the support revealed that the improvement of the catalyst activity was possible but limited. A high concentration of Mn–Na–W favours the formation of a smooth cristobalite phase and strongly decreased the number of active sites. The silica support was replaced by silica-free supports to limit the formation of cristobalite. The use of SiC as a support led to the formation of cristobalite near the surface of the catalysts but the porous SiC skeleton, which remained non-oxidised at the core of the catalysts, allowed maintaining a high surface area. SiC supported catalysts thus presented higher activities than silica catalysts. The use of α-alumina support led to catalysts with lower performances and revealed that exposed alumina was detrimental for the catalyst performance. Keywords OCM Ethylene SiO2 SiC α-Al2O3 1 Introduction Natural gas is widely used as a feedstock for the production of chemicals and energy with proven abundant reserves of over 150 and 200 trillion m3 as potential reserves [1]. It is estimated that approximately 30% of the natural gas reserves are stranded. Building liquefaction plants or pipelines is not economically viable in these cases. Conversion of natural gas to liquid hydrocarbons (GTL) has shown to strongly improve the economics of these stranded sources via the transport of valuable liquids [2]. However, most mature GTL processes require syngas as a feedstock which is produced via an energy intensive reforming step [3]. The oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) to ethane and ethylene has been studied for many years as a potential alternative route for the production of valuable hydrocarbons from natural gas without going through reforming [4–6]. Many catalysts have been screened for this reaction, but the C2 yields (ethylene and ethane) are always below 25% [7–10]. The use of micro-reactor technology might offer a solution for these limitations through better temperature control in OCM reactors [11–13]. This compact and integrated technology also fits well with the constraints of stranded natural gas locations [14]. Among the tested catalysts for OCM, two different families of catalysts have shown to be stable with C2 yields around 20%. Catalysts based on lanthanum and strontium oxides exhibit high activity and average C2 selectivity [15]. Catalysts based on silica-supported manganese, tungsten and sodium exhibit high C2 selectivity but low activities [8]. Previous studies have reported the deposition of stable coatings of silica-supported catalysts [16] and lanthanum-based catalysts [17] in stainless steel channels. Due to its higher C2 selectivity, the Mn–Na–W catalyst is currently one of the most studied catalysts. Olivier et al. stressed that the C2 productivity of this catalyst is five times lower than that of lanthanum-based catalysts [15]. The low activity of this catalyst hinders its use in micro-structured reactors. These reactors are suitable for highly active catalysts, which present poor performances in classical fixed bed reactors due to slow heat and/or mass transfer [11,18]. On the other hand, the use of La-based catalysts is limited by their intrinsically low selectivity. Their poor C2 selectivity is related to the presence of active sites that catalyse the direct oxidation of methane into CO x . Martin and Mirodatos [19] suggested that these sites are inevitably formed on lanthanum-based catalysts via the lattice oxygen equilibrium occurring during the OCM surface reactions. Subsequently, extensive studies have been carried out to determine the optimal formulation of non-reducible oxide catalysts [15]. The 10/20wt% La–Sr on CaO has been reported as an optimal formulation [20]. The Mn–Na–W catalysts usually present 2–8wt% of Mn, Na and W [8], and the silica support is partially converted into inert cristobalite [21]. Ji et al. [22] varied the relative concentration of Mn–Na–W with respect to each other and observed that 0.5–2wt% Mn, 0.8–1.6wt% Na and 2.2–4wt% W corresponded to the optimal catalyst performance. Contrary to LSC catalysts, the Mn–Na–W catalysts consist of large amounts of inert material. Supposedly, the concentrations of Mn, Na and W could be increased to enhance the activity per gram of catalyst. Studies have been carried out with increased concentrations of these elements [21,22]. These studies focused on the relative increase of one or two elements in relation to the other elements. To our knowledge, no study has been carried out with the increase of all the elements relative to the support. Each element of the complex Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst has its specific role in the OCM reaction. From previous studies, Arndt et al. concluded that the presence of tetragonal tungsten oxide was the key for the catalyst activity [8]. Manganese acts as an oxygen supplier for the tungsten active centres due to its high electronic conductivity [8]. However, the presence of sodium and silica is mandatory too, since the tungsten-support interaction is also partly responsible of the formation of OCM active centres. The role of sodium is more controversial. Its role in the change of silica to cristobalite is well known. Hamid et al. [23] have shown that amorphous silica led to a high methane conversion and poor C2 selectivity at 800°C. Under OCM conditions, amorphous silica catalyses methane reforming [24]. The change of silica into an inert support is mandatory to avoid the unselective reactions of the gas mixture with the catalyst support. The formation of cristobalite on Mn–Na–W catalysts has been reported as responsible of the extensive loss of surface area [21]. Sodium also appears to favour the phase change of hexagonal tungsten to active tetragonal tungsten. Manganese-tungsten catalysts were prepared on previously prepared cristobalite by Palermo et al. [21]. They showed significantly lower activity and selectivity toward ethylene and ethane than the regular Mn–Na–W catalyst. The poor performances of these sodium-free catalysts confirm the mandatory presence of sodium for the stabilisation of these tetragonal tungsten active centres. The objective of this study is thus to increase the activity of Mn–Na–W catalysts while maintaining their intrinsically high C2 selectivity. The concentration of Mn, Na and W was thus increased with respect to the support. The influence of the change of silica to cristobalite on the catalyst performances was also addressed via the analysis of the catalysts texture and the use of silica-free materials, SiC and α-Al2O3, as supports. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The 10/20wt% La/Sr on CaO catalyst was prepared via the nitrate and citric acid sol-gel method [15]. Hydroxides were diluted into distilled water. EDTA (ethylenediamineacetic acid, Sigma) was added to the mixture and NH4OH was added to obtain a clear solution (n[EDTA]=sum of n[hydroxides]). Citric acid was dissolved into water (3M, n[CA]= n[EDTA]) and added to the first mixture. The final mixture was then heated to 90–100°C to evaporate most of the water. Heating was stopped when a “gel-like” solution was obtained. The gel was then calcined in air according to the following procedure: 2h at 120°C, 3h at 300°C, 3h at 400°C and finally 10h at 1000°C. Temperature ramps were fixed at 1°C/min. The Mn–Na–W catalysts were prepared via wetness impregnation of the supports [25]. Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (Sigma) and Na2WO4·2H2O (Sigma) were dissolved in water and then added to three different supports. The mass ratio between the elements Mn–Na–W was fixed at 2:1:4wt% to comply with the optimum relative composition determined by Ji et al. [22]. The concentration of each catalyst is expressed in the corresponding tungsten concentration. Thus the Mn–Na–W catalysts studied here will be referred in wt% W on the support, the concentrations of Mn and Na will be two and four times lower than W, respectively, for all samples. The catalysts were first fired at 400°C for 10h in air to form the metallic oxides and then at 1000°C for 2h in air to ensure the stability of the catalyst under OCM conditions. The first support is silica Davisil 635 (Sigma) with a particle diameter of 40–70μm, a surface area of 480m2/g and a pore size of 150Å. Samples prepared with the silica support will be referred to as Mn–Na–W/SiO2. Four different concentrations of Mn, Na and W were synthesised with W concentrations of 2.8, 11.5, 19.5 and 41.0wt%. The 2.8wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 sample is similar in composition as the optimised catalyst reported by Ji et al. [22] and it is referred to as the reference sample. Silicon carbide was also used as a support for Mn–Na–W catalysts. A nanocasting method reported elsewhere was used to prepare porous SiC [26]. Samples are referred to as Mn–Na–W/SiC. Two different concentrations of Mn, Na and W were synthesised with W concentrations of 19.5 and 41.0wt%. Porous α-alumina supports were also synthesised for the Mn–Na–W catalysts. The support synthesis was performed via a forced hydrolysis method [27]. Al2(SO4)3·16H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 1 L of water with concentrations of 2×10−3 and 610−3 mol/L, respectively. The solution was heated to 100°C for 3h and stirred overnight at room temperature. Alumina powder was filtered and washed with water. The resulting powder was calcined at 1100°C for 1h at a 5°C/min rate to form the α-alumina phase. Samples are referred to as Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3. Two different concentrations of Mn, Na and W were synthesised with W concentrations of 19.5 and 41.0wt%. 2.2 Catalysts testing and characterisation Catalyst activity was measured in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (internal diameter=4mm) placed in an electric tubular oven. The catalysts were pelletised, crushed and sieved to a particle diameter of 200–300μm. 20–25mg of catalyst was diluted with 500mg of quartz particles (200–300μm). The catalysts activities and selectivities were measured at 800°C, atmospheric pressure and a mixture of CH4/O2/N2 of 16/4/1. Prior to experiment, catalysts were pre-treated at 1000°C for 2h under an air flow to ensure its subsequent stability. The space time is reported as the W/FCH4 ratio, while using the above mixture. The catalyst bed temperature was monitored with a thermocouple (Ø 0.25mm) placed inside the catalyst bed. The effluent gases from the reactor were analysed by micro gas chromatography (μGC 3000, SRA Instruments, France). CO2 and the C2 were separated on a PLOT U column with a PLOT Q pre-column at 70°C with helium as carrier gas. H2, O2, N2, CH4 and CO were separated on a Molesieve column with a PLOT U pre-column at 100°C with argon as carrier gas. Gas concentrations were measured by a thermal conductivity detector. XRD analyses of the catalyst powders were obtained using a Bruker D5005 diffractometer with a Cu K radiation at λ =1.541.08Å. XRD graphs were subsequently compared to XRD data collection from the Highscore and EVA software packs. XPS measurements were performed on an Axis Ultra DLD from Kratos Analytical using an Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV, 150W) with pass energy of 40eV. The scan step sizes were set at 1eV for an entire scan and then 0.1eV below the 50eV area and 0.2eV above this area. The analysed surface composition corresponded to approximately five atomic sublayers. The C 1s band at 284.6eV was used as a standard for the XPS analysis. Subsequently, the following elements were analysed: Na 1s, Mn 2p, Si 2p, W 4f, C 1s and O 1s at 1071, 641.0.3, 103.1, 35.2, 284.6 and 530.3 (for metal oxides) and 532.5eV (for silicon oxide), respectively. Elementary analysis of the Mn–Na–W samples was performed via ICP-AES on a Jobin Yvon Activa Spectrometer D ICP-OES. Each sample was dissolved in an acid solution (fluoric, nitric or sulphuric acids). The resulting solution is subsequently injected in the spectrometer and atomised via a plasma torch. Characteristic radiations of the elements from the sample are quantitatively measured. BET surface areas were measured by nitrogen adsorption of catalyst particles at 77K on a BELSORP-Mini (Bel-Japan). Samples were degassed under vacuum (around 10−4 mbar) overnight prior to analysis. Prior to surface measurement, each sample was fired at 800°C for 5h in air to match OCM conditions and then desorbed at 300°C for 12h under vacuum. The synthesis of porous a-alumina gave very low yields. Only 20mg of sample was available for BET analysis. The results of this analysis were inconclusive, indicating that the BET surface area was much lower than 1m2/g. 3 Results and discussion Catalytic performances of both the La/Sr/Ca and the 2.8wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 (reference) catalysts are compared in Fig. 1 . For the La/Sr/Ca catalyst, the methane conversion increased with increasing space time while the C2 selectivity decreased from 42 to 35%. A 30% methane conversion was reached with this catalyst at a space time of 1250gs/mol. The Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst presented a significantly lower activity since a 10% methane conversion was reached at a space time of 2500gs/mol. This activity corresponds well with that reported by Ji et al. [22]. They reached approximately 30% conversion at a contact time at least 3 times higher, assuming a catalyst bulk density of 800kg/m3. The C2 selectivity of 60–65% for this catalyst was higher than the La/Sr/Ca catalyst. The C2 selectivity is comparable to the 63% of Ji et al. [22]. At a 10% methane conversion, the activity of the La/Sr/Ca and 2.8wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts were 700 and 40μmol of converted methane/gcat s, respectively. This agrees with the difference of activity measured by Olivier et al. [15] between both catalyst types. 3.1 Influence of the Mn–Na–W loading on silica on the catalysts performances In order to increase the activity of the Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst, the concentration of Mn, Na and W on the Davisil silica were increased. Fig. 2 presents the influence of the concentration of Mn, Na and W (expressed in wt% W since the ratios Na/W and Mn/W are constant) on the catalytic activity at 10% methane conversion (the total flow rate was varied to obtain 10% conversion). Two different trends can be observed in Fig. 2. A linear increase is observed between the activity and the tungsten concentration between 2.8 and 19.5wt% of W. The apparent activity measured between these concentrations at 10% methane conversion increased from 42 to 111μmol/gs. Secondly, at a 41.0wt% W concentration, the activity dropped to 10μmol/gs. At 10% CH4 conversion, 60±2% C2 selectivity was measured for the catalysts containing between 2.8 and 19.5wt% of W. A low selectivity of 10–20% was observed over the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. The linear increase of the activity with increasing tungsten concentration shown in Fig. 2 indicates that the support is not saturated with active elements at low loadings, thus a large part of the catalyst was composed with inert cristobalite. Moreover, a similar C2 selectivity was observed for these Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts. This suggests that the equilibrium between the active elements and the support, which leads to active and selective catalysts, was maintained between loadings of 2.8 and 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2. However, a less active catalyst was obtained at 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2. 3.2 Surface characterisation of the Mn–Na–W-silica catalysts 3.2.1 XRD analysis To unravel the phenomenon that led to the less active 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst, XRD analysis was performed and compared with the active 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. Fig. 3 shows the XRD results of the calcined 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst and 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. After the thermal treatment at 1000°C the catalysts phases consisted of cristobalite, Na2WO4, Mn2O3 and different quartz phases (mainly tridymite). Samples were calcined at 1000°C for longer time and showed similar structures suggesting that the phases present at 1000°C were stable. Crystalline phases were similar between the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 and the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts. The formation of cristobalite and subsequent formation of tridymite and Na2WO4 were observed for both catalysts. However, the tridymite phase was predominant over the cristobalite phase for the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. Similarly, the higher loading of Mn, Na and W for this catalyst led to a more important presence of Na2WO4 phase compared to the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. Since the Na2WO4 phase has been previously considered as the active phase [24], a higher activity of the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst than the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst should have been observed. The low activity of this catalyst cannot be explained by its structural characteristics alone. 3.2.2 Catalysts composition analysis The Mn–Na–W/SiO2 samples were analysed by XPS to measure the surface concentration of Mn, Na and W. The XPS measurements were compared to the results by ICP-AES and are reported in Table 1 . An approximately two-times lower Na concentration was measured by ICP than the theoretical loading for all catalysts calcined at 1000°C. The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 sample calcined at only 400°C presented a significant higher Na concentration than the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 sample after the 1000°C heat treatment. This suggests that Na evaporated during the high-temperature heat treatment. The ICP concentrations of Mn and W were in agreement with the theoretical loadings for the 2.8 and 11.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts. However, the difference between theoretical and ICP loadings became larger at higher loadings. Mn concentrations measured by ICP were around 10–15% lower than the theoretical loadings for the 19.5 and 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts. For the same catalysts, W concentrations are 15–25% lower by ICP compared to the theoretical loadings. It appeared that the preparation of catalysts via wetness impregnation led to loss of Mn and W for highly loaded catalysts. The near-surface composition measured by XPS showed a significant increase of the Na concentration compared to the ICP analysis. The Na concentration near the surface has increased approximately 17 times compared to the catalyst concentration. An increase in the Na concentration could also be observed for the catalysts with higher loadings; the ratio between near surface and catalyst concentrations reached 2.7 for the 11.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst and 2.1–2.2 for the 19.5 and 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts fired at 1000°C. The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 sample fired at 400°C presented a lower Na concentration near the surface than the concentration measured by ICP. Apparently, during the heat treatment, sodium migrated from the inner parts of the catalysts to the near-surface area. After a heat treatment at 1000°C, most of the sodium was thus located close to the surface. Similarly, the tungsten concentration near the surface (XPS) is higher than the catalyst concentration (ICP) for all catalysts. The tungsten migrated like Na during heat treatments. Since the XRD analysis showed that Na and W were present in a single Na2WO4 phase after heat treatments at 1000°C, this phase contains most of the Na and W and is mainly present near the catalyst surface. Comparison of the Mn concentrations by ICP and XPS showed that the near-surface Mn concentration was lower than the bulk Mn concentration measured by ICP after heat treatments at 1000°C. The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst fired at 400°C presented a 23% higher loading of Mn in the near-surface area than in the bulk. After the heat treatment at 1000°C, the same catalyst presented a 60% lower Mn concentration near the surface. The Mn, Na and W concentration of the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 followed the same trends observed for the lower loading catalysts. This catalyst presented higher bulk (ICP) and surface (XPS) concentrations of active elements than the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. The low activity of the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 could thus not be explained by its bulk or surface compositions. 3.2.3 Textural analysis Direct observation of the catalysts was performed via scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Fig. 4 presents the SEM images of the Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts with different concentrations of Mn, Na and W on silica. EDX analyses were performed on different spots (1μm3 of sampling) of the crystallites observed on the SEM pictures. They show that these crystallites were composed of mixed phases of Mn, Na, W and Si. Their size increased with increasing concentrations of Mn, Na and W. Crystallites were on the order of magnitude of 5–10μm for the 2.8wt% catalyst. They reached 15–20μm for the 11.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 4b). Finally, at higher loadings, no crystallites could be observed any longer and large crystallites, larger than 25–30μm, were observed for the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 and 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts. Moreover, the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst presented a remarkably smooth surface. The crystallite size and the catalysts smoothness of the surface increased with increasing Mn, Na and W concentration. The surface area of the catalysts decreases with increasing crystallite size, thus an very low surface area of the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst can be expected. BET surface areas were measured for the 2.8, 19.5 and 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts and are reported in Table 2 . The surface area decreased with increasing Mn, Na and W loading. With a surface area of 0.15m2/g for the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst, this catalyst presented a texture close to the sphere model (∼0.05m2/g). This low surface area was in agreement with SEM analysis (Fig. 4d). The catalyst activity seems to be related to the product of the surface concentration of the Mn, Na and W and the BET surface area. To confirm these assumptions, the catalytic activity was plotted versus the product of the BET surface area and the concentration of Mn, Na and W, as presented Fig. 5 . The activity was measured at 800°C, 16/4/1 CH4/O2/N2, at 10% methane conversion and 0.04 volume fraction of catalyst. Indeed a linear correlation is observed. It shows that the low activity of the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst is related to its low number of active sites caused by its low surface area. Palermo et al. [21] have reported that the low surface area of silica-supported Mn–Na–W catalysts was caused by the transformation of the silica support into cristobalite and different quartz derivatives, such as tridymite, with time on stream. The structural change of silica to cristobalite occurred at temperatures above 1400°C in the absence of additives. However, the addition of sodium in the case of Mn–Na–W catalysts acted as a fusing agent and caused the structure to change at 700–800°C. The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst presented a lower surface area than the 2.8wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 because of the higher concentration of sodium. Further increase of the sodium concentration led to a severe decrease of surface area as observed on the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. As the use of sodium is necessary for a good catalytic performance in the Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalysts it cannot be omitted to avoid the formation of cristobalite. Thus an alternative way to avoid loss of surface area at high loadings due to the formation of cristobalite is replacement of silica as a support. The support should be inert under OCM conditions. Liu et al. [28] have tested Mn–Na–W impregnated on a SiC monolith under OCM conditions. Their results of catalytic activity and selectivity were promising, but were compared with a silica based Mn–Na–W catalyst in powder form. No direct comparison was performed between silica and SiC based Mn–Na–W catalysts in powder form by Liu et al. [28]. 3.3 Silicon carbide as support for the Mn–Na–W catalysts As the specific surface area of the Mn–Na–W catalysts is a key parameter for the catalysts performances, a SiC support with a large surface area was prepared via Shi's method [26]. SEM analysis and BET surface area measurement confirmed that the synthesised SiC was porous with a crystallites size between 1 and 2μm. Fig. 6 shows large cavities in the support and a BET surface area of 700m2/g was measured via nitrogen adsorption. Two Mn–Na–W samples were prepared with the nanocasted SiC support: - 19.5/8.8/4.9wt% Mn–Na–W - 41.0/19.5/10.5wt% Mn–Na–W After 24h under a methane/oxygen stream during OCM operation at 800°C, the two catalysts were again analysed by SEM. These SEM images are presented in Fig. 7 . Both catalysts presented larger crystallites than after the thermal treatment at 400°C. The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst presented a surface with similar large cavities as the initial SiC support. Although the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst presented a smoother surface, the surface was apparently rougher than the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst from Fig. 4d. Moreover, EDX analysis on three locations per micrograph showed that the crystallites of both catalysts contain mixed phases of Na, W, Mn and Si. Catalytic activity of the Mn–Na–W/SiC catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. Significantly higher activities were observed for catalysts using SiC as a support with similar concentration of Mn, Na and W compared to silica as support. A 45% improvement of the catalytic activity of the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 was observed when SiC is used as support. Moreover, a nine times activity improvement was observed with the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst compared to the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. The C2 selectivity for both catalysts was around 60–65% similar to that of the silica supported samples (except the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2). The results suggested that the catalysts were similar in structure. To verify this assumption, XRD analysis was performed on the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC and the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst and compared to the silica supported catalyst that showed the highest performances; the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. The resulting XRD diffractograms are reported in Fig. 8 . The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 and 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalysts presented similar XRD patterns; their main crystalline phases were Na2WO4, Mn2O3 and cristobalite. Contrarily to the silica catalyst, only the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst presented traces of tridymite. The presence of cristobalite in the SiC catalyst suggested that the silicon carbide support is oxidised during the thermal treatment. A similar oxidation of SiC was observed by Liu [29] when silicon carbide was mixed with alumina. Although the oxidation of SiC in air is an extremely slow process even at temperatures between 1200 and 1400°C, the mixture of SiC with an oxide significantly increases the rate of the SiC oxidation. Oxygen consumed for the silicon carbide oxidation is directly delivered by the alumina. During the Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst preparation, SiC is intimately mixed with manganese, sodium and tungsten oxides, which bring molecular oxygen to the support thus oxidising it at 800°C. To confirm that the surface of silicon carbide was fully oxidised, the near surface and bulk composition of the SiC-supported were analysed via XPS and ICP and compared with the silica supported catalysts at similar loadings. First, it can be stressed that carbon was not detected via XPS on the SiC samples, the oxygen concentrations of these samples at the near-surface area were similar to the concentrations measured on silica-supported samples. This confirms that SiC was completely oxidised into silica at the surface. The comparison of theoretical concentrations of deposited elements with the concentrations measured via ICP was consistent with the differences observed in the case of silica-supported catalysts (Table 1): - Between 30% and 50% of Na disappeared from the catalyst during the heat treatment, probably via the vapourisation of a sodium compound. - Between 20% and 25% of W was lost during the catalyst preparation thus the W concentration measured by ICP is lower than the theoretical concentration. - The Mn concentration measured via ICP was close to the theoretical concentration. Moreover, similar differences between the XPS and ICP concentrations could be observed for the SiC or silica supported catalysts for the 19.5wt% W loading. The near-surface area consisted of a Na/W mixture—in a Na2WO4 phase according the XRD analysis—and Mn was located below this mixture. The Mn concentration at the surface was lower than the bulk concentration. The higher activities observed for SiC catalysts than silica catalysts could neither be related to different active phase nor structural differences. To unravel the differences of activity between SiC and silica catalysts, the textural parameters of SiC catalysts were analysed via surface area measurements by N2 adsorption as presented in Table 2. The initial SiC support had a specific surface of 700m2/g and the formation of cristobalite at the SiC catalysts surface led to a severe loss of surface area with 0.7 and 0.3m2/g for the 19.5 and 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalysts, respectively. However, it appeared that the surface areas of SiC catalysts were higher than their silica supported equivalents. Since the support had no influence on the concentration of the active elements at the same theoretical loading, the density of the active sites related to the S BET*Conc(Mn,Na,W) parameter was higher in the case of SiC catalysts. The high activity of 160μmol/gs measured with this catalyst at a 0.04 volume fraction was consistent with its high active site density. This is shown in Fig. 5. The trend for the SiO2 supported catalysts continues for the more active SiC based samples. To avoid the formation of cristobalite and the subsequent loss of surface area, the support of Mn–Na–W catalysts should be replaced by silicium-free materials. The requirement of an inert material at high temperatures drastically reduces the list of available materials. Previous studies have shown that most oxides that can be used as support present a non-negligible activity toward the methane conversion which is particularly unselective [23,30]. Interestingly, corundum (alumina) has been reported as an inert material toward the partial oxidation of methane with oxygen at 650°C [31]. Moreover, Kim et al. [32] reported a significantly lower activity of an α-alumina support toward OCM than mixed oxides. The α-alumina can thus be considered as a potential replacement of silica because of its low activity toward methane oxidation and the absence of a smooth cristobalite structure on the support. 3.4 Alumina The preparation of a porous α-alumina is, however, problematic [33]. The procedure requires calcinations above 1000°C for the phase transition of the ɣ-alumina to the less active α-alumina. Alumina tends to collapse after these thermal treatments. Roh et al. [27] have shown that the synthesis of a porous α-alumina was feasible. However, the alumina synthesised via their method had a significantly lower surface area of 76m2/g than the SiC support studied above. The α-alumina support prepared via forced hydrolysis method from Roh et al. [27] presents a rough surface with aggregated spherical crystallites (Fig. 9 ). 3.4.1 Textural properties of alumina-supported Mn–Na–W catalysts The SEM images of both alumina supported catalysts shown in Fig. 10 show that both catalysts presented a rough surface after a 1000°C thermal treatment. Fig. 10a shows that the spherical shape of the alumina support could still be observed on the 19.5wt% W catalyst after OCM operation. Moreover, large crystallites (above 5μm) consisting of a Mn–Na–W mixture were present on the catalyst. Unlike for the 19.5wt% W on silica or SiC catalyst, the intimate mixing of the Mn–Na–W elements and the support was not observed. In contrast, the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3 showed large crystallites of 20–30μm with mixed phases of Mn–Na–W–Al (Fig. 10b). This suggests that the impregnated elements completely covered the alumina support. Similarly to the Mn–Na–W/SiC catalysts, both alumina supported catalysts presented rougher surfaces than the silica-supported catalysts for the respective amount of Mn–Na–W. No surface area measurements of alumina catalysts were performed because of the low amount of catalysts prepared. The preparation method of Roh et al. [27] gave yields of α-alumina below 5%. 3.4.2 Catalysts performances and composition Table 3 reports the alumina-supported catalysts performances in terms of catalytic activity and C2 selectivity. The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3 catalyst presented a high activity of 160μmol/gs. This activity was similar to the activity reported for the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst around 0.04 of catalyst volume fraction. However, the C2 selectivity at 10% methane conversion was limited to 6% and the SiC-supported catalyst reached 60–62% under the same conditions. For the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3catalyst, a 45μmol/gs activity and a C2 selectivity of 60% was observed. The C2 selectivity of this catalyst matched the selectivity previously reported for Mn–Na–W catalysts at 10% methane conversion, but the catalytic activity was two times lower than the 111μmol/gs activity of the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst at 0.04 of catalyst vol. fraction. The α-alumina Mn–Na–W samples were analysed by XPS and ICP to calculate their near surface and bulk compositions (Table 1). Comparison of the bulk composition of the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3 with its theoretical composition showed that the actual Na and W concentrations were close to the theoretical loadings. However, Mn presented a significantly lower concentration measured by ICP. This suggested that part of Mn was not deposited on the catalyst during the active elements impregnation. For the near-surface composition, both α-alumina catalysts presented high concentrations of Na and Mn compared to silica-supported catalysts. The Mn and Na concentrations were two times and 30% higher, respectively, for alumina-supported catalysts. The disappearance of Mn from the catalyst surface was not observed for alumina catalysts contrarily to silica or SiC catalysts. Moreover, the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3 catalysts presented a 27.1wt% concentration of alumina at its surface which was 27% higher than the Si concentration at the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst. This confirmed the observation from the SEM analysis in Fig. 10; the catalyst surface contained large crystallites consisting of a Mn–Na–W phase and the alumina support. Mixed Mn–Na–W-support phases were not present on the surface. Large areas of the alumina support were exposed. This suggested that the alumina support of the 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3 catalyst contributed to the quenching of free radicals, including methyl radicals that are the key intermediates for ethane formation. On the contrary, the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3 presented a low near-surface concentration of Al compared to 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2. As observed by SEM, mixed phases of Mn–Na–W–Al were present on the catalyst surface. However, due to the high concentration of Mn in the near-surface area, the relative contribution of Mn to W at the catalyst surface was thus different for silica or SiC supported catalysts. The study of Ji et al. [22] has shown that the performances of Mn–Na–W catalysts were highly sensitive to the relative contributions of each element from the Mn–Na–W system. The authors reported that the positive influence of the Mn addition on Na–W on silica catalysts goes through a maximum and that higher Mn loadings inhibit the catalyst activity. The resulting low activity of the 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W/α-Al2O3 catalyst can thus be explained by the too large contribution of Mn. It can be concluded that the replacement of silica by alumina as support for Mn–Na–W catalysts did not lead to an improvement of the catalyst performance. The low performance of the alumina based catalyst is probably due to the large part of alumina not covered by active elements. Better performance with alumina based catalysts might be obtained at different active elements ratios covering the complete surface area. 3.5 Catalysts comparison The performances of the catalysts used in this study have been summarised in Table 3. Compared to the 2.8wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 reference sample, the catalytic activity could be increased 2.7 times while maintaining a selectivity of 60–65% via the increase of the loading of Mn, Na and W (19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2 catalyst). Moreover, the replacement of silica by silicon carbide as a support increased the activity further to 160μmol/gs. This activity was 45% higher than the best performing silica catalyst. Subsequently, SiC catalysts presented the highest ethylene productivities among the different supports tested. The 19.5wt% Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst thus reached 18μmol of ethylene/gcat s. It should be stressed that the LSC catalyst reached 40μmol of ethylene/gcat s. Despite the improvement of the Mn–Na–W activity, the resulting ethylene productivity of the La/Sr/Ca catalyst remained two times higher. The analysis of the catalysts surface composition showed that silica and silicon carbide catalysts had similar Mn, Na and W concentrations. Moreover, both types of catalysts presented Na2WO4, Mn2O3 and cristobalite as the main surface compounds. Surface silicon carbide was oxidised into silica. The higher activities of the silicon carbide catalysts could be attributed to their higher surface areas at similar loadings as the silica catalysts. This led to higher number of active sites per gram of catalyst. The presence of silicon enabled the migration of Na and W at the catalyst surface as well as the transport of Mn into deeper layers. The replacement of silicon-based support by α-alumina hindered this configuration and led to high concentrations of Mn at the catalyst surface. Ji et al. [22] reported that high concentrations of Mn at the catalyst surface led to the formation of mixed Mn-Si structures–mainly inactive MnMn6SiO12–that covered the active sites of the Mn-W-Na phases. The unravelling of the OCM active site of the Mn–Na–W catalyst remains complicated. Most of the studies suggest that methyl radicals are formed after reaction of methane with tetrahedral WO4 species [8]. Sodium favours formation of these W species as well as their dispersion over the catalytic surface [21,34]. Ji et al. [22] measured the methane conversion over Mn–Na–W catalysts at fixed Mn and Na concentrations, but with increasing W concentration and reported a direct correlation between the W concentration and the catalyst activity. Arndt et al. [8] suggested that Mn acts as an oxygen donor to the W active centre since hydroxyl radicals with a hydrogen from methane and an oxygen from the catalyst surface are formed in the step of methyl radicals production. Palermo et al. [21] showed that the absence of Mn in the Mn–Na–W catalyst was not detrimental to the performance. However, Ji et al. [22] reported significantly lower activities of the catalysts at low Mn concentration. Manganese acts mainly as an activity promoter. Based on the above literature analysis and from the present results, it can be concluded that the performances of the Mn–Na–W catalysts are related to a delicate elemental configuration at the surface: - The Na2WO4 phase is located at the catalyst surface and the availability of WO4 determines the performances of the catalyst. - Mn species are located below Na2WO4 and act as oxygen donors to the WO4 centres. Estimation of the active sites density can be performed with the direct use of the addition of the atomic concentration of the active elements. The parameter S BET*conc(Mn,Na,W) correlates the impact of the textural properties and the composition of the catalyst on its performances as shown in Fig. 5. The use of this parameter showed that the positive influence of high loading of 41.0wt% of Mn, Na and W on the catalytic activity of 41.0wt% Mn/Na/W was limited by the dramatic loss of surface area. XPS analysis showed that the Mn–W–Na species represented over 60wt% of the catalyst surface. This suggests that most of the catalyst pores were filled with these elements leading to a smooth surface at this loading. However, the large difference of loadings between 19.5 and 41.0wt% Mn–Na–W suggests that an optimal loading might be found within this range. Further gain in activity might be possible if one manage to synthesis support materials exposing a high surface area at elevated OCM temperatures. One then needs to make sure that all this surface area is covered with active elements leading to a high number of active sites and to avoid total oxidation on the support. 4 Conclusions Catalysts based on the Mn–W–Na are widely studied standard catalysts for OCM due to their high selectivity toward ethylene and ethane. The reference OCM catalyst is the 1.4/0.7/2.9wt% Mn–Na–W/SiO2. This catalyst present a high C2 selectivity of 60–65% at 10% methane conversion, but a very low activity of 40μmol CH4/gcat s compared to the 700μmol CH4/gcat s activity reached by the La-based catalysts. At equal methane conversion, the Mn–Na–W catalysts presented 60–65% C2 selectivity whereas La-based catalysts were limited to 40% C2 selectivity. The low concentration of Mn–Na–W impregnated on the reference catalyst offers the possibility to improve the activity of the Mn–Na–W catalyst, by increasing their concentration. The increase of the concentration of Mn–Na–W on silica to 4.8/8.9/19.5wt% Na/Mn/W increased the catalyst activity to 110μmol CH4/gcat s while maintaining the C2 selectivity. However, a further increase of the loading led to a poorly active catalyst. This was due to the formation of cristobalite, which caused a drastic decrease of the catalyst surface area. To prevent the formation of the smooth cristobalite, silica-free supports were studied as replacement of silica in Mn–Na–W catalysts. Silicon carbide as a support showed the formation of SiO2 and cristobalite at the surface, but the core porous SiC skeleton remained non-oxidised thus maintaining a high surface area and subsequent high activity. The use of α-alumina showed no formation of cristobalite. However the absence of silicon led to a different surface composition than silicon-based supports, resulting in poor OCM performance. The 4.8/8.9/19.5wt% Na/Mn/W on SiC presented an OCM activity of 160μmol CH4/gcat s with a C2 selectivity of 60–65%. An ethylene productivity of 18μmol/gcat s could be reached with this catalyst. The use of SiC instead of silica as Mn–Na–W support gave a four times higher activity than the reference catalyst. Despite these improvements, the activity of the optimised Mn–Na–W/SiC catalyst remains far from the activity of La/Sr/CaO. The maximal ethylene productivity of the Mn–Na–W catalyst is thus below the productivity of 40μmol/gcat s of the La/Sr/CaO catalyst despite the higher selectivity of the Mn–Na–W catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Mn–Na–W silica supported catalysts are highly selective toward ethylene and ethane in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) process. However, they present lower activities than La/Sr/CaO catalysts and subsequently a lower ethylene productivity. Optimisation of the Mn–Na–W catalysts has been focused within the range of 2–8wt% of active elements relative to the support, while silica is partially converted into inert cristobalite. This study focused on the increase of the activity of Mn–Na–W catalysts while maintaining their intrinsically high C2 selectivity. The increase in the concentration of the active elements with respect to the support revealed that the improvement of the catalyst activity was possible but limited. A high concentration of Mn–Na–W favours the formation of a smooth cristobalite phase and strongly decreased the number of active sites. The silica support was replaced by silica-free supports to limit the formation of cristobalite. The use of SiC as a support led to the formation of cristobalite near the surface of the catalysts but the porous SiC skeleton, which remained non-oxidised at the core of the catalysts, allowed maintaining a high surface area. SiC supported catalysts thus presented higher activities than silica catalysts. The use of α-alumina support led to catalysts with lower performances and revealed that exposed alumina was detrimental for the catalyst performance.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of the composition/texture of Mn–Na–W catalysts on the oxidative coupling of methane
